recommendations: Peter Czerniawsky “Captain Snarzyk (ret. U.S. Army) Brian, to his friends and colleagues: brings his legacy as a "member of the thin grey line" with him in his briefcase and his heart to everything that he does. I do not believe that you could get Brian to do an unethical act under threat of death. He is an Executive that in the age of Enron, Andersen, MCI and Tyco his peers can only envy. I worked directly for Brian on an number of occasions but the engagement that I take greatest pride in is when Brian, who reported directly and had personal responsibility, under the immediate direction of Major General Peter Kind (ret. US Army): gave me sole responsibility for designing the "National Disaster Information Technology Infrastructure" for the President of the United States under executive order in the fall of 1998. Brian acted as my translator to the General and his team and was able to convey the extremely technically complex aspects of my design to the General in a manner that (as a non-technologist) he and his team were unable to grasp unaided. My design was based solely on the necessarily complex and highly technical design documents that the Presidential Executive Order Mandated. I consider Brian both a mentor and a friend and would not hesitate to provide him my professional services should he ever require my level of technical knowledge. Any organization would be doing their stock holders an extreme disservice by not meeting Brian's terms: no matter his requirements. Brian is man of both thought and action and should be given the highest respect for his past actions and his future potential; a potential that can only be expected to increase his standing in the Corporate and Government worlds of America.”

publications.title: How to Transform P&C Core Systems
publications.subtitle: Insurance Thought Leadership
publications.description: Many projects fail to fully realize their potential benefits due to three oversights. The insurance industry continues to invest heavily in transforming their legacy policy, billing and claims applications. But are carriers actually realizing what was promised to the business? Core transformation can be so much more than a legacy technologyreplacement.In our experience, many projects fail to fully realize their potential benefits due to three common oversights:Digitization without differentiation – Projects that simply upgrade their core systems but fail to change the customer engagement.Limited focus on information data – Too much focus on transactional data elements and not using a comprehensive informational data approach.Failure to foster innovation – Modernizing applications but failing to leverage these tools to support continuous improvement and innovation. In fact, 67% of insurance respondents to PwC’s 2017 CEO survey see digitalization and innovation as very important to their organizations. Specific to the insurance industry, CEOs noted that the area they would most like to strengthen to capitalize on growth opportunities is digital and technological capabilities, followed by customer experience (reflecting the connections between the two).Insurers are looking for more than just modernization of core systems. They expect a successful digital, analytics and organizational transformation that can enable them to unlock the full potential that a core transformation has provided to them. Carriers should be asking themselves the following questions to determine if they’re achieving the full benefits of expanding beyond core. Is the organization:Leveraging the new platform to change the customer engagement model?Leveraging analytics-based insights with a clear vision and plan to translate that into value based capabilities?Promoting continuing innovation – both internally and to customers?

publications.title: PwC - Top Insurance Issues 2018: Expanding Beyond Core Transformation
publications.subtitle: PwC Advisory Services
publications.description: Carriers should be asking themselves the following questions to determine if they’re achieving the full benefits of expanding beyond core. Is the organization:Leveraging the new platform to change the customer engagement model?Leveraging analytics-based insights with a clear vision and plan to translate that into value based capabilities?Promoting ongoing innovation – both internally and to customers?Regardless of where they are on their core transformation journey, there are several opportunities carriers can leverage to unlock the full potential of a transformation, including in:Digital differentiationData and analyticsInnovationInsurTechAudience: CIO, CTO, COO, core systems leadership and personnel

publications.title: Top Insurance Industry Issues 2017
publications.subtitle: PwC
publications.description: Top Insurance Industry issues for 2017 focuses on the challenges and opportunities facing various aspects of the industry including core transformation.This publication touches on the fact that insurers are looking for more than just up-to-date systems. They also want digital and analytics platforms that can help them realize the full benefits of a core transformation. Insurers are getting ambitious with their transformation initiatives. Looking forward, a successful transformation should include broader strategies for 1) data analytics, 2) a positive digital customer and agent experience, and 3) underwriting efficiency.

publications.title: Top Insurance Industry Issues 2015
publications.subtitle: PwC
publications.description: The insurance industry is facing once-in-a-generation disruption. Top Insurance Industry Issues in 2015 discusses the challenges and opportunities confronting insurers, and provides insight on how to adapt to change.Carriers are focusing on the “transform” in core transformation. Read this publication to see the benefits of core transformation.

publications.title: 3 Policy Admin Conversion Considerations
publications.subtitle: Insurance Networking News
publications.description: Moving your policy data from one policy administration system (PAS) to another may sound simple — it’s logistics, right? In reality, the conversion process is much more complex and critical to the overall success of transformation initiatives than most people realize.

publications.title: The Soft Stuff Is Often The Hardest: Change Management Critical In PAS Transformation
publications.subtitle: Carrier Management
publications.description: PwC has learned in helping property/casualty insurance carriers implement new policy admin systems, noting that change management is often considered the soft side of transformation. This article describes that to the contrary, the process of managing the change, and in particular its impact on customers and employees' expectations and activities - is critical to delivering hard cost reduction and product flexible benefits.

publications.title: PAS as a Launchpad for Improved Customer Experience
publications.subtitle: Insurance & Technology
publications.description: Building a business case for PAS transformation on market responsiveness alone can be a challenge. Executives often will demand verifiable benefits, complete with expense ratio and headcount reductions that justify the return on investment for what is a major initiative. While verifiable benefits are important, executives should realize that policy administration transformation also is a foundational investment that creates a launch pad for enabling new and innovative capabilities. With a modern platform, carriers can more efficiently and proactively respond to changing market demands instead of being passed by the competition.

publications.title: Gaining Operational Leverage from a Policy Administration Replacement
publications.subtitle: Insurance & Technology
publications.description: Improved operating leverage will provide the most direct and immediate benefits. Justifying the cost of a policy administration replacement can be a challenge for carriers because some of the benefits are indirect and don't surface until years later. For this reason, the case for a transformation isn't as straightforward as for other core systems transformations, like claims or billing.When building a business case for policy replacement, carriers usually look for quick and direct benefits in two areas: operating leverage and market agility. The prospects of improving operating leverage are particularly compelling to carriers because they often immediately impact the business, whereas market agility benefits take some time to realize as carriers identify new products and markets to enter. A PAS replacement can result in improvements to operational processing, eliminate redundant legacy systems, and increase IT delivery assurance, thereby enabling both immediate and long-term cost reductions. However, not all operating leverage related benefits are direct — in fact, in the long run, you may find that the indirect benefits have the largest impact on overall profitability.

publications.title: Ready, Fire, Aim! -- Don't Miss the Point of a Policy Administration Transformation
publications.subtitle: Insurance & Technology
publications.description: The convergence of aging legacy platforms, complex market demands, and a more mature vendor landscape have ushered in a unique period of policy administration transformation where it is possible for carriers to embark on this journey by taking on less risk than before but carriers who misinterpret the business drivers of their transformation programs risk firing at the wrong target.Before moving forward with a policy administration transformation, it's important for carriers to fully understand their business case, product mix, geographical presence, distribution channels, and overall market dynamics. Carriers planning policy administration transformation must evaluate specific business drivers as a diagnostic for assessing how a transformation will impact profitability.

detailed_profile.name: Octavio Arellano
detailed_profile.position: Business Developer; Project Promotion and Evaluation; Strategic Planning
detailed_profile.about: He is currently engaged in Business Development, Project Promotion and Evaluation, and Strategic Planning as an independent consultant. Previously he was an external consultant to Cal y Mayor y Asociados, an engineering and consulting firm in Mexico City, specialized in transport, infrastructure, energy and ICT projects. In this capacity, he formulated the business plan and financial model of the winning bid in the multipurpose maritime terminal of Veracruz port public tender for Infraestructura Portuaria Mexicana (IPM), on December 2017. From September 2015 to June 2016, he worked as director in PriceWaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Mexico, for the regional platform Hispanic America Advisory Services (HAAS). As such, he participated in the research and writing of the report “Future of the Pacific Alliance”, in which strategic proposal were made and investment and public policy opportunities were identified within the four member countries (Chile, Colombia, Peru and Mexico), in nine key sectors: education, health, mining, oil and gas, value-added manufacturing, electricity and renewable energies, financial services, physical and digital connectivity. In the period July-September 2016, he worked as director in the Infrastructure and Capital Projects division of PwC’s advisory services. Starting October 2016, he was an independent business promotor and advisor. As such, he agreed to join efforts with Kapsis, Ports and Coasts, an engineering consulting firm, specialized in ports and coastal development and projects, in order to promote the update of port development master plans and investment projects with global players within public-private partnerships.

detailed_profile.name: Srikanth R
detailed_profile.position: Senior Manager | PwC | Deals
detailed_profile.about: Consulting leader with 18+ years of global experience across data strategy, analytics, technology implementation, and large-scale transformation programs. I bring a unique blend of business insight, technical expertise, and delivery excellence, to help clients solve complex challenges—particularly in context of Deals. 🔹 Areas of Specialization • Deal analytics and data strategy across sectors (TMT, BFSI, GRC, Supply Chain) • Divestitures, financial statement carve-outs, and entanglement analysis • Data harmonization, cost optimization, and enterprise-wide reporting • Possess a strong understanding of accounting concepts and ERP Systems. 🔹 Current Role at PwC Advisory Services, Washington, DC • Senior Manager leading high-impact deal engagements across the US and India • Analyze complex ideas or proposals and provide meaningful solution and recommendations for the practice and our clients. • Identify synergies, efficiencies, and cost savings opportunities associated with the project and find ways of automating tasks. • Drive end-to-end delivery including client workshops, data transformation, and executive readouts • Collaborate directly with CXOs, Product Heads, and Operations Leaders to design scalable analytics solutions • Mentor and grow a diverse team of consultants, building strong delivery culture and capability 🔹 Previous Experience • Over a decade in BFSI consulting with Oracle Financial Services, focused on FLEXCUBE UBS implementations • Led multi-country core banking deployments across leading banks in Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, and Greece • Deep expertise in solution architecture, gap analysis, customization, UAT, and post-production support 🔹 Technology & Tools • Languages & Platforms: Python, SQL, PL/SQL, T-SQL, Microsoft Azure, Oracle, Postgres • Data & Automation Tools: Alteryx, UI Path, Excel • Visualization & Reporting: Power BI, Tableau 🔹 Passionate About • Solving complex business problems using data-centric strategies • Enabling decision-making through actionable analytics and financial storytelling • Fostering a culture of continuous learning, mentorship, and operational excellence • Bridging business and technology to drive meaningful transformation Let’s connect if you’re working in the deal space, driving digital finance initiatives, or building future-ready analytics teams.

basic_info.name: Joe Deegan - Managing Director at Alvarez & Marsal
basic_info.search_snippet: Joe retired as a partner/principal from Ernst & Young LLP (EY) after 30 years of providing value and impact to his clients, community and team.

detailed_profile.name: Joe Deegan
detailed_profile.position: Managing Director at Alvarez & Marsal
detailed_profile.about: Joe is a Managing Director of Alvarez & Marsal's Corporate Transactions Group in Atlanta. He specializes in helping corporate clients realize accretive value with their M&A transaction strategy and execution, focusing on operational diligence, post-merger integration and deal synergy realization. Prior to A&M, Joe retired as a partner/principal from Ernst & Young LLP (EY) after 30 years of providing value and impact to his clients, community and team. Joe currently serves as an investor and advisor to Sapien Software. Sapien Software is a proven, rapidly customizable HRIS solution built and priced for global mid-market companies and delivering everything from global employee/position and benefits administration to PTO, compensation management, global payroll integration, performance management, corporate directory, succession planning, organizational charting, position/entity control, intuitive employee and manager self-service, and more. At EY, Joe most recently served as the Deputy Leader of EY’s Americas People Advisory Services (PAS) practice. The PAS practice is a global EY sub-service line with over 13,000 employees in more than 130 countries, offering deep industry knowledge and experience to more than 2,000 corporate clients worldwide. EY PAS helps clients harness the power of their people agenda – the right people, with the right capabilities, in the right place, for the right cost, doing the right things. Joe has significant experience working as an advisor and consultant to controlling shareholders, company boards and senior executives. He has also been an EY M&A practice leader supporting companies that are seeking to accelerate their growth through acquisitions, alliances, divestitures and/or joint ventures. Joe has significant HR and operational transactional experience in assisting his clients realize value in acquisitions, restructurings, divestitures, joint ventures and HR transformations. He also has extensive experience in executing and developing growth strategies, HR effectiveness, operational cost reduction, strategic sourcing and large-scale program management. Throughout his career, Joe has worked with clients in multiple industries including consumer goods, healthcare and manufacturing. Joe also has significant international experience, working on global projects spanning more than 60 countries, including spending significant time in China, France and the Netherlands.

detailed_profile.name: Shaoni Rakshit
detailed_profile.position: Jill of All Trades, Mastering Brand & Marketing Strategy.
detailed_profile.about: As a non-verbal kid, I spent my early years glued to the TV. Some of the first words I ever spoke were ad jingles. Marketing, quite literally, gave me my voice. I’ve been chasing the power of communication ever since. Today, I bring that voice into everything I do. Whether it’s building brand identities, mapping campaign strategy, or writing the words that shape a user journey. My work blends storytelling with structure: I’ve crafted media proposals, reimagined company decks, designed sitemaps and low-fi wireframes, built social campaigns, and developed buyer personas backed by deep research and competitive benchmarking. I’ve led projects, mentored teammates, and owned verticals. In my last role, I became a conceptual lead within weeks. I thrive in spaces where strategy meets sensitivity, where insight translates into action, and where creative systems are designed not just to look good, but drive impact. I think in stories because that’s where I come from. I once convinced a teacher I’d ridden a camel simply because I’d read about it in a Satyajit Ray novel. I hadn’t even seen a desert yet. That moment taught me something: narrative, when done right, can reshape reality. With a background in literature and a lifelong writing practice, I approach every project with a blend of empathy, elegance, and precision. I care about the rhythm of things: how language moves, how visuals feel, and how strategy aligns with soul. Off the clock, I’m improving my spoken French, shaping Urdu letters by hand, and writing poems when PowerPoint can’t quite hold the feeling. Some of my writing lives in a published Amazon anthology and other corners of the internet: it’s been shaping the way I build brands and tell stories long before I even knew what a brand was. Currently, I’m exploring opportunities in brand strategy and creative leadership — spaces where I can keep turning ideas into systems, and stories into action. Rambles, roles, or rabbit holes: send them my way at shaonirak@gmail.com!

recommendations: Sreyoshi Guha Thakurta “I had the pleasure of working with Shaoni for around four years, and in that time, she became one of the most dependable and quietly brilliant writers I’ve collaborated with. Shaoni has that rare mix of thoughtfulness and precision in her writing. She doesn’t just put words on a page: she listens, she thinks and she questions. Whether it was narrative-driven work, editorial pieces, or content with tight brand constraints, she brought clarity and depth every single time. She’s also incredibly easy to work with. She is very reliable, receptive to feedback, and thoughtful in ways that go beyond the brief. There were countless moments where her ability to just get it saved time and lifted the overall quality of the work. If you’re looking for someone who can think deeply, write beautifully, and bring calm competence to your team, Shaoni is your person. I’d work with her again in a heartbeat.”

Debarshi Ghosh “I've had the pleasure of working alongside Shaoni Rakshit, and I can confidently say she's one of the most versatile and impactful content strategists I've met. Her ability to craft compelling brand narratives and develop sharp content strategies has directly contributed to rapid growth for several startups. What sets Shaoni apart is not just her command over content, but her cross-functional expertise. Whether it’s SEO optimization, market research, or shaping the bare-bones structure of a project from scratch—she steps in with insight, energy, and precision. Her talent for gathering scattered information and transforming it into a clear, actionable roadmap is remarkable. She doesn’t just write content; she builds strategy, brings in clients, and drives business outcomes. Any team would be lucky to have her.”

basic_info.name: Kim Hong Chua
basic_info.search_snippet: Kim Hong has extensive experience providing advisory services to clients to support their M&A activities across the entire deal spectrum.

detailed_profile.name: Kim Hong Chua
detailed_profile.position: Transactions Partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP
detailed_profile.about: Kim Hong has extensive experience providing advisory services to clients to support their M&A activities across the entire deal spectrum, including but not limited to due diligence services, completion reviews and sales & purchase agreements review. Kim Hong was also seconded to PwC New York in 1997 to broaden her skills set in due diligence work. She was worked on numerous transactions with deal values in excess of US$10 billion across the Asia Pacific region including Australia, Hong Kong, China, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Philippines and Vietnam. Kim Hong worked with numerous corporate and private equity investors, across industries such as oil & gas, consumer services, retail, industrial manufacturing and real estate. Kim Hong graduated with honors from the Nanyang Technological University with a Bachelor of Accountancy. She is a Certified Public Accountant and a member of the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Singapore.

recommendations: Chris Gassman “Collaborating with Carolyn during our term on executive board of the Net Impact Chapter at Carnegie Mellon helped keep me on my toes and focused on the endeavors that made the most strategic sense. Whether it was me sound-boarding projects I was the lead responsible for (e.g. Zero Waste Initiatives at Tepper and across Campus) or us working together on broader cross-cutting endeavors (e.g. Sustainable Careers, Force For Change Award, etc.), she was consistently coming at the micro details with the macro view in the forefront of the conversation. This enabled us to consistently tackle: how these endeavors meshed with where we wanted the Chapter to go, how they fit in amongst everything else we were doing, as well as how our stakeholders would value and respond to all of this. Carolyn has a natural eye for strategy and those who have the opportunity to work with her are sure to notice the value she brings to the table.”

Frank Cordek “Hands down - Carolyn was one of the best team mates I had on numerous endeavors in business school. It began with the Deliotte case competition, which our team of four took first place, and continued through numerous finance classes. Any time I had the opportunity to put together a team, Carolyn was a first choice. Not only is she an excellent team player, but she also possess intangibles to help other team members relax and find their strong points.”

The joy in my professional life comes from : - being challenged on an idea; - realising something what wasn't there before; - being on the move and keep on developing; - working with people and feel the power of a team.

basic_info.name: Tim Boehm
basic_info.search_snippet: Consulting executive focused on strategy, IT leadership and IT operations. SCORE Mentor to small business; Non-profit advisor; Founder Canter Advisory Group ...

detailed_profile.name: Tim Boehm
detailed_profile.position: Consulting executive focused on strategy, IT leadership and IT operations. SCORE Mentor to small business; Non-profit advisor; Founder Canter Advisory Group; PSU masters; Retired Principal - Deloitte Consulting .
detailed_profile.about: Following retirement from Deloitte, Tim started volunteer work as a Service Corp of Retired Executives Mentor advising new and small business owners in the establishment and growth of their businesses. He is also an advisor to non-profits, and a masters student at Penn State. Tim has over 30 years experience in the consulting industry with a primary focus on IT operations, application management, vendor relationships and outsourcing. He retired from his final role at Deloitte as the Global Energy, Resources and Industrials practice leader for Deloitte’s operate services. He served as account and engagement executive for multiple clients, customizing and delivering solutions that reduce costs, improve service and drive sustained value. He has assisted clients with their approach to outsourcing, optimization of their application portfolio, and the design of their IT operating model. Tim has led the modernization of IT operations through automation, process and organizational optimization, continuous improvement, and innovation. In his Deloitte leadership roles and prior, he led the development of automation and methodologies, published multiple whitepapers, and been quoted on the topic in publications such as Information Week, SAP Insider and the Associated Press. Prior to joining Deloitte, Tim led a variety of outsourcing and application management focused business units for mid-tier technology consultancies.

publications.title: Facebook Mobile Interfaces: A Heuristic Evaluation of Privacy Features
publications.subtitle: Proceedings of the Annual Information Institute Conference in Las Vegas, NV, USA
publications.description: Abstract:Users increasingly access Social Networking Services like Facebook using mobile devices.The use of the Social Networking Services brings with it privacy issues. Several studies have focused on users of desktop computers. However, few studies focus on access via mobile applications. Thus, there is a gap in understanding how the use of mobile applications to access Social Networking Services impact on the privacy-related behaviour of users. As a first step to cover this gap, this paper explores mobile user interfaces of various Facebook mobile applications in a systematic manner. Firstly a set of general user interface heuristic principles are identified from the literature. This set is then explored through a privacylens, deriving good practice heuristics for privacy features of applications. Finally, theprivacy features of the iOS, Android and Blackberry Facebook applications are evaluated using the derived list of privacy heuristics recommendations. The paper shows that numerous shortcomings exist within privacy features of Facebook mobile applications.

basic_info.name: Chris Thomas
basic_info.search_snippet: As a principal in Deloitte Consulting LLP, I specialize in hybrid cloud, AI, data center, and core technology infrastructure.

detailed_profile.name: Chris Thomas
detailed_profile.position: US Hybrid Cloud Infrastructure Leader at Deloitte
detailed_profile.about: For more than 25 years, I have had the privilege of leveraging my strategy consulting and engineering experience to help clients drive large-scale technology transformations and develop hybrid cloud-centric operating models. Today, I am proud to serve as Deloitte’s US Hybrid Cloud Infrastructure Leader, where I lead Deloitte’s US AI & Engineering team’s Hybrid Cloud Infrastructure business to help organizations optimize their hybrid cloud strategies and build future-ready enterprises. As a principal in Deloitte Consulting LLP, I specialize in hybrid cloud, AI, data center, and core technology infrastructure. In leading Deloitte’s US hybrid cloud services, my focus is on delivering measurable value for clients by engineering and operating solutions that harness the power of modern cloud technologies and Deloitte’s strategic cloud alliances, ensuring both optimization and resilience. I am passionate about the transformative potential of hybrid cloud technologies and believe they offer organizations a unique opportunity to maximize the value of their technology investments. In addition, I regularly share insights on hybrid cloud infrastructure and emerging technologies through platforms such as The Wall Street Journal’s CIO Journal, Deloitte’s Tech Trends, industry forums, and technology publications. I hold a B.S. from Miami University (Ohio) and a M.S. from Northwestern University.

publications.title: Demystifying cyber insurance coverage: Clearing obstacles in a problematic but promising growth market
publications.subtitle: Deloitte University Press
publications.description: Organizations continue to invest heavily in cybersecurity efforts to safeguard themselves against threats, but far fewer have signed on for cyber insurance to protect their firms after an attack. Why not? What roadblocks exist, and what steps could the industry take to help clear them?

publications.title: Quantifying risk: What can cyber risk management learn from the financial services industry?
publications.subtitle: Deloitte University Press
publications.description: Quantitative models to measure cyber risk—the same kinds of models widely used by financial services firms—are starting to gain broader acceptance. But risk managers may be led astray if they rely too much on models out of context. What lessons in effectively using models does the financial services industry hold for cyber risk management?
